Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program (CSDM) of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Dor Ben-Amotz of Purdue University and his graduate and undergraduate research students will use hydration-shell vibrational spectroscopy (especially Raman scattering spectroscopy), nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) and other experimental, computer simulation, and theoretical modeling strategies to address key questions pertaining to water-mediated processes occurring molecular interfaces, including how solute molecules influence water structure and how such structure changes influence water-mediated chemical interactions.

The results will be use to better understand and predict how water participates in processes of relevance to the biological self-assembly as well as green chemical manufacturing, geological petroleum recovery, and environmental remediation. Besides the broad impact of the research on several areas of science, Prof. Ben-Amotz will continue to provide his research students with excellent training in the development and application of experimental and theoretical tools and innovation strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interfacial water-mediated structural transformations play a central role in biological, geological, and environmental processes, many of which involve interactions between water and molecules containing non-polar (oily) and polar (ionic and dipolar) interfacial regions. The structural and energetic interactions between water molecules and such interfaces drive a myriad of molecular binding, recognition, and self-assembly processes. This grant was focused on addressing key open questions regarding water’s structure at molecular hydrophobic interfaces and it’s role in mediating aqueous chemical processes. This was done by combining Raman scattering with multivariate curve resolution and spectral entropy minimization, as well as using our new theoretical finite lattice analysis. These experimental and theoretical modeling strategies were used to better understand the interactions between oily molecules in water, as well as between salts and oily molecules in water, of relevance to biological self-assembly processes. 


The results obtained during the first year of this grant addressed important open questions regarding water-mediated interactions, including the interactions of water with oily molecules and ions. The results of these studies are described in articles published in Nature Chemistry, Journal of the American Chemical Society-Communication, and Faraday Discussion.  During the second year of this grant, theoretical finite-lattice random mixing and weighted random mixing descriptions were developed to predict and interpret the probability that a given molecule will come into contact with one or more other molecules or ions in water.  The results of this work (which was carried out in collaboration with Prof. Ben Widom at Cornell University) were reported in two publications in the Journal of Physical Chemistry B, and one in Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys., as well as a chapter in a book entitled Aqua Incognita. Additional results pertaining to the interactions neutral and charged molecules and oil-water interfaces (carried out in collaborations with Sylvie Roke at EPFL in Switzerland) were reported in the Journal of the American Chemical Society-Communcation and Angewendte Chemie. The most significant outcome obtained during the final year of this grant is the finding that water-mediated interactions between small oily molecules in water are weaker than those between the same oily groups in the gas phase.  This conclusion follows from work described in the Journal of Physical Chemistry-Letters (done in collaboration Huib Bakker at AMOLF in Amsterdam) as well as a subsequent invited perspective article in the Journal of Physical Chemistry-Letters, and a recently published Annual Review of Physical Chemistry entitled "Water Mediated Hydrophobic Interactions".
